full_conversation: Therapist: Let's begin the imaginal exposure. Close your eyes and take a deep breath.
Client: Okay, I'm trying. My heart is already racing...
Therapist: You're doing great. Take your time.

Client: I see myself at the airport. My son Miguel was leaving for a business trip. I remember hugging him tightly, not wanting to let go. He promised to call when he landed. I watched him walk through security, waving one last time before disappearing into the crowd.
Therapist: Good. Stay with that memory.

Client: I went home and tried to distract myself by cooking dinner for my grandchildren. But I couldn't shake this uneasy feeling. As I was chopping vegetables, the phone rang. It was Miguel's wife, her voice trembling. She said there had been an accident. The plane... it had crashed shortly after takeoff.
Therapist: You're doing well. Keep going.

Client: I... I dropped the knife. My legs gave out, and I collapsed onto the kitchen floor. I couldn't breathe. My chest felt so tight. I kept thinking, "No, no, it can't be true." I wanted to wake up from this nightmare.
Therapist: It's okay to feel those emotions. You're safe here.

Client: The next few hours were a blur. Family members started arriving. The house was filled with crying and disbelief. I remember sitting on the couch, staring at the wall, unable to process what was happening. My daughter held my hand, but I couldn't feel it. I was numb.
Therapist: You're handling this well. Continue.

Client: The days that followed were torture. Identifying his body, planning the funeral... it all felt surreal. I kept expecting Miguel to walk through the door, laughing about some big misunderstanding. But he never did. At the funeral, I couldn't even cry. I just felt... empty.
Therapist: It's natural to feel that way. You're doing great.

Client: After everyone left, that's when it really hit me. The silence in the house was deafening. I found myself in Miguel's old room, clutching his childhood teddy bear. That's when I finally broke down. I cried for hours, screaming, asking why. Why him? Why my son?
Therapist: Allow yourself to feel those emotions. You're safe.

Client: The pain... it was physical. Like someone had ripped out a part of me. I couldn't eat, couldn't sleep. Every time I closed my eyes, I saw the plane crashing. I imagined Miguel's fear in those final moments. Was he thinking of me? Did he suffer?
Therapist: Stay with it. You're doing incredibly well.

Client: Months passed, but the pain didn't lessen. I started having nightmares about planes crashing. I couldn't bear to see airplanes in the sky. I avoided the airport at all costs. Even the sound of a plane overhead would send me into a panic attack.
Therapist: You're very brave for sharing this. Keep going.

Client: I felt so guilty for being alive while my son was gone. I started to withdraw from everyone. My chronic pain got worse. I couldn't focus on anything. It was like a part of me died with Miguel that day. And I... I don't know how to live without that part of me.
Therapist: It's okay to feel this way. You're doing great.

Client: Sometimes, I still expect him to call. Every time the phone rings, there's a split second where I think it might be him. And then reality crashes back, and the pain is fresh all over again. I miss him so much. I just want my son back.
Therapist: You're very courageous. Take a deep breath.

Client: I'm trying to be strong for my grandchildren, but it's so hard. They remind me so much of Miguel. I see him in their smiles, their laughter. It's both comforting and painful. I want to be there for them, but some days, the grief is just too overwhelming.
Therapist: You're doing an amazing job. How are you feeling now?
Client: I... I feel drained. Talking about it brings back all those feelings. But somehow, I also feel a little lighter. Like I've shared some of the burden. Is that normal?
Therapist: Absolutely. You've done incredibly well today.

Client: Thank you. It's still so painful, but maybe... maybe talking about it like this can help. I want to learn how to live with this grief, for Miguel's sake. He wouldn't want me to suffer like this forever.
Therapist: That's a powerful realization. We'll end here for today.
